moves.1. e4: This is a game against fellow Southern Chess member tnaptguy. He named this game "My game is in the toilet!" However, his game seems to be very good, from my viewpoint. We play a very even game...
moves.1... e5 2. Nf3 d6: ? I don't like opening the diagonal for Bb5. I never have. If I play the common Bb5  he has many sensible replies, but he would have to respond to MY move, as opposed to making one of his own accord.
moves.3. d4: If it's a fight for the center he wants, it's a fight he'll get!
moves.3... f6: !? Tricky. That e5 square must be very important to Black...
moves.4... dxe5 5. Bc4: Quick recap. I have two minor pieces developed whilst Black has only his two pawns. However, there are no pieces in front of the queens...
moves.5... Qxd1+: ...cat fight! Black opts to force my king to lazily move.
moves.6. Kxd1 Bc5: Now that he has unearthed the king, it's time to attack the exposed pieces.
moves.7. Be3: White does NOT want this exchange. An exposed king doubled pawns=trouble
moves.7... Bb6: ? Thankfully, it doesn't happen. However, this is questionable. He is inviting me to double one of HIS pawns? I'm sure he had a plan, but I don't see it.
moves.8. Bxb6 axb6 9. Bxg8: ?? What on earth is White doing? He has left his king totally exposed! In truth, I feared 9. ... O-O for this reason. I need his rook to have trouble developing.
moves.9... Rxg8 10. Re1: Now MY rook is free, whilst my bishop move has stalled his matching rook.
moves.10... b5: ? I don't know what this was for.
moves.11. b4: ?! I guess that Black's previous move was an attempt at control of the queen side. so I refute this.
moves.11... Nc6: Now I am THANKFUL for my previous pawn move. I can safely refute his assault.
moves.12. a3 g5: ! Now he's coming on the KING side, but my defense is clear.
moves.13... Be6: ! Nice positional move! His bishop now controls many more squares than before, plus it opens the path for castling.
moves.17. Nxf6: !? Very risky. Black has attacking chances from many angles and white commits a pawn grab while guarding d7 from a doubled rook scenario.
moves.17... Nxf3: Opening the door for his rook to advance while doubling my pawns.
moves.18. gxf3 Bxh3 19. Ng4: !! Although it allows Rg-e7, it traps the bishop while threatening e5. White no longer fears the doubled rooks.
moves.19... Re7: Necessary to save his e5 pawn.
moves.20. Re3: ?! What is this? It weakens White's back rank considerably, plus it does nothing to refute doubled rooks. A mistake...or a trap?
moves.20... Red7 21. Rd3: ! Oh! White wanted to plug the nasty hole in his d file with a rook of his own.
moves.21... Rd7xd3 22. cxd3 Rxd3 23. Nxe5 Rd8: ? Black fails to see all of White's threats.
moves.28. axb5: !! Intentionally doubles his own pawns to set up a discovered back rank attack! This move could really hurt if all pieces are exchanged, but White has no intention of that.
moves.28... Rxf3 29. Ne5: !! Simultaneously attacking the rook, protecting the pawn, and...
moves.29... Rf1+: Black elects to put pressure on the king.
moves.30... Rf4: ??? Seems serviceable, but black has completely lost scope here. He is fighting for the center and does not see his demise!
moves.31. Ra8#: Mate. I'm fairly certain that my opponent will stare at the board for a second and wonder why he cannot move to d7. On 29. Ne5, I did not reveal the THIRD item that was attacked: an escape square! Great game, tnaptguy. Thanks for watching! :)

gameName: My game is in the toilet!
